newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia, Indonesia to discuss timber smuggling.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia, Indonesia to discuss timber smuggling.

text.p: Malaysia's primary industries minister will meet his Indonesian counterpart to discuss the smuggling of Indonesian timber into the east Malaysia state of Sabah, the Bernama news agency said.

Lim Keng Yaik, who will visit Indonesia in the next few weeks, said he would urge the Indonesian authorities to tighten curbs on smuggling timber into Malaysia, the national news agency said late on Monday.

"While Malaysia has done its part, Indonesia still needs to take serious efforts to control it (smuggling), especially by increasing enforcement in the border areas," Bernama quoted Lim as telling reporters.
Timber smuggling came to light last month after a Japan-bound ship was intercepted in Malaysia's Sabah state on Borneo island with a cargo of logs worth six million ringgit ($2.4 million).
Timber company executives in Sabah said the logs were illegally felled in Indonesia's Kalimantan province on Borneo island and smuggled into Sabah for re-export.
Indonesia has long banned all log exports.
The Malaysian government has launched a probe into the timber smuggling.
